bestBHT.bht: The Jews' gratuitous and deep-seated hatred towards Jesus, the promised Messiah, fulfilled God's purpose. Their pride in the law that condemned them blinded them to truth, making them deserving of condemnation. They followed in their fathers' footsteps, who hated David without reason. This sin of hating without cause is considered heinous and equated to grave transgressions. It serves as a reminder that to hate without cause is a serious offense, patiently endured for God's purpose.

Henry Alford: To suppose any irony in these words, as De Wette does (‘they are true followers-out of their law’), is manifestly against, the whole spirit of our Lord’s reference to the law.
It is called ‘their law,’— 'the law which they are ever turning over and vaunting themselves about,' as Bengel says,—as condemning them, though their boast and pride.
The citation is probably from Psalm lxix., which treats of the rejection and sufferings of the Messiah.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: 25. that the word might be fulfilled
. . . They hated me without a cause—quoted from the Messianic
Albert Barnes: He injures no one, but, amid all their hatred, he seeks their welfare; and, while they reject him in a manner for which they 'can give no reason in the day of judgment,' he still follows them with mercies and entreats them to return to him.
Who has ever had any reason to hate the Lord Jesus? What injury has he ever done to any one of the human race? What evil has he ever said or thought of any one of them?
Yet no being on earth has ever been more hated, despised, or neglected, and in every instance it has been 'without a cause.'
Marvin Vincent: Without a cause [δωρεαν] . Gratuitously. Akin to didwmi, to give. Their hatred was a voluntary gift.
John Calvin: But nothing is more contrary to reason than to hate God; and, therefore, Christ says that so great was the malice with which their minds were envenomed, that they hated him without a cause.

He calls it their Law, not as an expression of respect for them, but to wound them more deeply by a designation which was well known among them; as if he had said, 'They have a Law transmitted to them by hereditary right, in which they see their morals painted to the life.'
they were in no respect better than their fathers, who hated David without a cause.
Philip Schaff: They had condemned their fathers because of the persecutions to which God's Righteous Servant of old had been exposed: yet they 'filled up the measure of their fathers.'

Their pride and carnal dependence upon outward descent from Abraham blinded their eyes to the distinction between truth and falsehood, right and wrong, and made them do what they acknowledged in the light of Divine truth, of Scriptures which they honoured, to be worthy of condemnation in their own fathers.
The very law of which the Jews boasted, and into which, from imagined reverence for it, they were continually searching, in that very law they might see themselves.
Archibald T. Robertson: The hatred of the Jews toward Jesus the promised Messiah is 'part of the mysterious purpose of God' as shown by ινα πληρωθη.
Without a cause (δωρεαν). Adverbial accusative of δωρεα from διδωμ, gratuitously, then unnecessarily or gratis.
The allusion is to Psalms 69:4 (or Psalms 35:19).
John Gill: - 1. "This hatred against Christ, and which is pointed at his people for his sake, and reaches to the Father also on his account, is suffered to be, and therefore should be patiently borne.
- 2. "This sin of hating without a cause, is represented by the Jews as a very heinous one, and as the reason of the destruction of the second temple.
- 3. "To teach us, that hatred without a cause is equal to the three (capital) transgressions, idolatry, adultery, and murder, for which they say the first temple was destroyed.

They despised Him without cause, a gratuitous hatred that is contrary to reason. The reference to their law highlights their continual boast and pride in the very law that condemned them. In their rejection of Jesus, they followed in the footsteps of their fathers who hated David without cause. This hatred, which reaches to the Father, is a sin that should be patiently borne, as exemplified by Christ Himself who sought their welfare despite their animosity. Ultimately, it serves as a reminder that to hate without cause is a grave offense.
